https://prez.dev/description.@value: The primary purpose for which a borehole was drilled or any secondary purpose that the borehole may acquire during its lifecycle. The vocabulary focuses on drilling purposes within the resources industry, with a focus on terminology as applied in the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) databases. Some terms covered by jurisdictional legislation are highlighted in the provenance field. Variations in terminology within definitions (i.e. usage of borehole, well and wellbore) stem from usage in different sectors of the resources industry, but for the purpose of this vocabulary are considered to be equivalent. In the context of this vocabulary, the term fluid energy refers to sources such as gas, petroleum and geothermal, as covered by the Petroleum Legislation Amendment Act 2024, and is exclusive of mineral sources of energy (e.g. coal, uranium).
A well or bore drilled to recover strata samples for their use in acid leachate testing.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Environmental drilling is performed when soil, rock or groundwater samples are required to assess an area for contamination, or when groundwater monitoring wells or remediation wells are required for the treatment of groundwater. Typically this type of drilling is conducted for a) testing and monitoring for sites such as landfills or lagoons that have a potential for pollution, b) monitoring and testing of environmentally sensitive sites such as protected lands or public water supply wellfields, c) testing to determine the source and extent of a known pollution problem, d) sampling and well construction for recovery or remediation of pollutants in groundwater, e) identification of product (oil, petrol etc.) or human artefacts (fill, trash, archeological).

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Environmental drilling is performed when soil, rock or groundwater samples are required to assess an area for contamination, or when groundwater monitoring wells or remediation wells are required for the treatment of groundwater. Typically this type of drilling is conducted for a) testing and monitoring for sites such as landfills or lagoons that have a potential for pollution, b) monitoring and testing of environmentally sensitive sites such as protected lands or public water supply wellfields, c) testing to determine the source and extent of a known pollution problem, d) sampling and well construction for recovery or remediation of pollutants in groundwater, e) identification of product (oil, petrol etc.) or human artefacts (fill, trash, archeological).

A borehole drilled to identify the physical and geochemical properties of materials and whether they have the potential to cause environmental harm and/or contribute to, or detract from, the success of rehabilitation and closure. This drilling focuses on identification of fibrous materials, radioactive materials, materials capable of generating acid and/or metalliferous drainage (including neutral drainage and saline drainage), and dispersive and/or erosive material.

An environmental borehole drilled to facilitate the collection of water, soil or rock samples to investigate potential contamination and the requirements for environmental remediation (e.g. cleanup, removal, containment) needed to reverse or stop environmental damage, or as part of the remediation process (e.g. pumping out groundwater for treatment or disposal).

A borehole/well drilled to identify the presence of stygofauna and facilitate the monitoring of its biodiversity and overall 'health' parameters. Stygofauna, also known as subterranean aquatic fauna, are aquatic fauna that inhabit the water filled pore spaces, voids, cracks and fissures of most rock types and groundwater systems such as aquifers or underground caves.
